Ooh interesting. Pretty neat and unique beat with a nice feel to it. 

Also, the game itself is just a wonderful blast to play with its high paced action and reaction stylistic gameplay!

snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: This definitely strikes me as something that works much better in the game than outside of it.
snippet.textOriginal: This definitely strikes me as something that works much better in the game than outside of it.

snippet.textDisplay: You can't truly appreciate Thumper's sound design outside of the game, especially without having experienced it. To me, Thumper is a nearly perfected rhythm game akin to others in the genre like Rez. The menacing, intense and repetitive beats absolutely accentuate the experience and helps you get in a trance I've rarely had while playing a game. And if you want to complete the very fast paced levels, that trance helps you focus and is almost necessary. At some points, I felt like my hands were moving the beetle automatically in the right directions. With each level being quite lengthy, I had to take breaks after each because my brain had enough. While the number of levels and their length are very welcome, I found the variety in gameplay elements and aesthetics to be lacking between each stage. I certainly think a sequel could revisit the concept and expand on its ideas. Overall, while I haven't played that many rythm games, I would certainly put it near the top of my favorites in the genre. I'm looking forward to playing it again with VR,
snippet.textOriginal: You can't truly appreciate Thumper's sound design outside of the game, especially without having experienced it. To me, Thumper is a nearly perfected rhythm game akin to others in the genre like Rez. The menacing, intense and repetitive beats absolutely accentuate the experience and helps you get in a trance I've rarely had while playing a game. And if you want to complete the very fast paced levels, that trance helps you focus and is almost necessary. At some points, I felt like my hands were moving the beetle automatically in the right directions. With each level being quite lengthy, I had to take breaks after each because my brain had enough. While the number of levels and their length are very welcome, I found the variety in gameplay elements and aesthetics to be lacking between each stage. I certainly think a sequel could revisit the concept and expand on its ideas. Overall, while I haven't played that many rythm games, I would certainly put it near the top of my favorites in the genre. I'm looking forward to playing it again with VR,

snippet.textDisplay: Aside from the points you brought up, this version of the soundtrack is super compressed and it just sounds ugly.
snippet.textOriginal: Aside from the points you brought up, this version of the soundtrack is super compressed and it just sounds ugly.

snippet.textDisplay:
SupraDarky 
Thumper was one of the games on my wishlist, and I'm about halfway through so far. I played the 4th level at a friend's house, and he told me he couldn't blink the whole time. 
This game's sound design is very well made, and the war-drum sound really made finishing a stage in a level satisfying, especially when you execute the timing flawlessly.
snippet.textOriginal:
SupraDarky 
Thumper was one of the games on my wishlist, and I'm about halfway through so far. I played the 4th level at a friend's house, and he told me he couldn't blink the whole time. 
This game's sound design is very well made, and the war-drum sound really made finishing a stage in a level satisfying, especially when you execute the timing flawlessly.
